body: Could you be more specific about what you expect which is wrong? The reproducible without more details/context makes it hard to look into this.
@dummdidumm it did the trick, thank you
you mean adding something else other than comments to do the trick?

probably that would be the solution, yes. I'm not sure though what to replace it with. Some `data-hydrate-head-start/end` attribute on the first and last element? Are `data-` attributes valid on these header tags?

My thought was whether we could add a dev mode warning that would warn no comments were found. I'm not sure if there's always at least one comment, but I suppose we could add a dummy comment if needed
So you're stance on this is "the minifier shouldn't remove those comments, and we should warn about it at dev time"?

issue.title: Service worker config aliases (#7496)
issue.body:
### Please don't delete this checklist! Before submitting the PR, please make sure you do the following:
- [x] It's really useful if your PR references an issue where it is discussed ahead of time. In many cases, features are absent for a reason. For large changes, please create an RFC: https://github.com/sveltejs/rfcs
- [x] This message body should clearly illustrate what problems it solves.
- [x] Ideally, include a test that fails without this PR but passes with it.

### Tests
- [x] Run the tests with `pnpm test` and lint the project with `pnpm lint` and `pnpm check`

### Changesets
- [x] If your PR makes a change that should be noted in one or more packages' changelogs, generate a changeset by running `pnpm changeset` and following the prompts. All changesets should be `patch` until SvelteKit 1.0

### Fixes #7496  

This PR splits the `get_aliases` function into two. One that returns aliases that are consumer-configurable, another that returns the 'stock' aliases (`__GENERATED__` and `$app`).

With this refactor, this PR also involves the config aliases in service worker builds, meaning service workers can import modules using custom aliases defined in `svelte.config.js`.

body:
> So you're stance on this is "the minifier shouldn't remove those comments, and we should warn about it at dev time"?

Yeah. It seems the easiest/safest fix. I think we use comments elsewhere for hydration

The suggested `html-minifier` config in the [svelte-kit docs](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/migrating#integrations-html-minifier) include `removeComments: true` so should that be corrected? Or perhaps there's a whitelist of patterns that `minifier` should ignore?

It's not clear from the docs that HTML comment nodes are required for hydration - or any other functions.

Lastly, does this also apply if the project is built as a pre-rendered static site - where `html-minifier` is run not as a hook but as a post-build task?

If you pre-rendered static site ships without any JavaScript (`export const csr = false`) and therefore hydration isn't needed, then you can turn it on. Good point about the example, will update the docs.

issue.title: [docs] update minifier example
issue.body:
Set removeComments to false, some hydration code needs them, so leave them in

issue.title: Duplicate `head` elements occur when html comments are stripped

repository.name: svelte
repository.description: web development for the rest of us

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

The [solution](https://github.com/sveltejs/svelte/pull/7745) to the duplicate content `svelte:head` element [bug](https://github.com/sveltejs/svelte/issues/6463) (and also [this one](https://github.com/sveltejs/svelte/issues/6463)) requires HTML comments to be present in order to function correctly. Many [minification tools strip HTML comments](https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/issues/7493#issuecomment-1303218382), and as does CloudFlare by default in many environments.

Duplicating the `head` element is a fairly insidious bug because it isn't immediately obvious that anything is wrong, but for our project (in SvelteKit) it decreased performance by loading analytics scripts multiple times. We also suspect that it may have broken some web indexing, but couldn't be sure.

If there is a better way to solve this than relying on comments, that would be great. I've marked the `Severity` as `annoyance`, but only because we have found a highly unsatisfactory workaround that I would rather not have in place long term.

### Reproduction

One straightforward way to reproduce this would be to use the [reproduction repo](https://github.com/thousandsofraccoons/double-meta) provided in [this issue](https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/issues/7493), which minifies the html response and strips comments: when comments are stripped, the duplicate header bug is present.

### Logs

_No response_

### System Info

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 12.6
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
    Memory: 90.36 MB / 16.00 GB
    Shell: 5.8.1 - /bin/zsh
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.15.1 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.15.1/bin/node
    npm: 8.11.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.15.1/bin/npm
  Browsers:
    Chrome: 108.0.5359.98
    Firefox: 105.0.2
    Safari: 16.1
  npmPackages:
    svelte: ^3.55.0 => 3.55.0
```


### Severity

annoyance

issue.title: Upgrade SvelteKit to 1.0
issue.body:
## Status:

 : Ready

## Description

- Upgrades SvelteKit to version 1.0
- Crazy that this ~netted 1 line~ reduced line count 

Things to think about:
- I removed the `loadImages` script from the build process, and everything still seems to work. I was wondering what the reason for it was before, if it was for an old SvelteKit bug or something to do with the Contentful image URLs? The reason I removed it is because I'd have to change the file paths it accesses since they're no longer valid. I _could_ do this though.
- I switched to the SvelteKit Netlify adapter because I'm anticipating some need for server-side JS soon (viewing preview content). All of the old content on the site is still prerendered, but now the build will include server-side JS for use in the future.
- For some reason the Netlify adapter is still able to deploy to Vercel... I have no idea why. Not a bad thing, just a thing.
- Had to disable comment removal minification option because Svelte has [an issue](https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/issues/7493#issuecomment-1303218382) with it.
- I was able to simplify the use of the `<Head` component by having pages return load data called `title`, and the layout uses it for setting a global `<Head`. While this adds some indirection, I think it's fine because of how much it simplifies, and TypeScript + autocomplete makes `title` appear inside the return statements of `load` functions.
- I had to pass the Contentful private environment keys into the `check` CI/CD jobs because they're statically replaced variables, so they have to be there for SvelteKit to successfully type check our app.
